Work About
Improving micro-mobility
services in New York City

Mobile application and landing page design

Project

Scope

The Challenge

While there are many options for micro-mobility services, their products can have a high barrier of entry (you need to create an account and set up payment for each service you’d like to use), they often don’t address road-safety concerns (once you access the device, you don’t necessarily get guidance on where you’re going and how to get there safely). Every app has different use patterns, so it can be confusing to toggle between services to understand how they work.

The Opportunity

Through Unicycle, we wanted to create a service where users of micro-mobility devices can more easily see available vehicles in their area, and feel more comfortable on the roads.

My Role

As part of a group project, my contributions were associated with User Research, and app interface design.

User

Research

Research Methodology

As a method of qualitative research was chosen, one-on-one interviews with the targeted audience were conducted.

Why?

A qualitative type of research was chosen because quantitative research in this step of the process won’t give necessary answers and won’t provide answers to the following questions:

  • What problems do users face when they want to use a micro-mobility service?
  • What product should I create?
  • What is important to users when they use micro-mobility services?
  • And how to solve these problems?

    • Interviews, in this case, are much more effective than surveys, as they provide an opportunity to collect in-depth information about people’s opinions, thoughts, experiences, and feelings.

    Research Goals

    Imbued with the user experience and understand their pain points and needs.

    Research Question

    To learn about users' interests, goals, and desires related to micro-mobility services.

    Research Objectives

  • Uncover participants' attitudes towards and thought processes around utilizing micro-mobility services
  • Understand the process, and tools participants use for accessing information about what micro-mobility services are in their area/available.

    • Interview Format

    Interviews were conducted via Zoom and in person.

    Information about Respondents

    The respondents’ names were changed to ensure confidentiality.

    We identified a group of potential representatives of the target audience who need to be involved in the interview:

  • People who are already using the micro-mobility services, but have some hesitations about them

    • Research

    Analysis

    User Insights

  • Users expressed interest in a micro-mobility service that would remove high barriers to entry (making it easier to sign up and use more services more casually).
  • Users have safety concerns, citing the lack of dedicated bike lanes, erratic driving, and worries about not having a helmet as significant deterrents to using micro-mobility services.
  • Users are concerned about how much effort it takes to be situationally aware of both safety and where they are and need to go.
  • Users like to ride for health and pleasure!
  • Users opt for low-cost transportation options.

    • User Empathy Map

    A user empathy map was created to consolidate the results of the interviews and identify pain points.

    Says

  • “I have to juggle all these different apps, subscriptions, and payment methods! I just want to find a ride and hop on.”
  • “Sometimes I get a bike or scooter that dies on me, so I end up taking a car anyway, which defeats the purpose of trying to reduce my carbon footprint and save money.”

    • Thinks

  • Micro-mobility options are a great way to incorporate exercise into travel, so he doesn’t have to carve out dedicated time in his schedule.
  • It’s unfortunate that micro-mobility options are not very functional during the winter months.
  • It would be nice if he could plan a route that is customized for micro-mobility options so he feels prepared to embark on his trip.

    • Does

  • Commutes between three boroughs for school, work, and home
  • Tries to do little things to be eco-friendly (e.g., use less plastic, reduce carbon footprint, etc.)
  • Forced into using ride-share apps like Lyft/Uber when in a rush and checking for micro-mobility options while mapping the route is taking too long.

    • Feels

  • Mentally exhausted from being hypervigilant while on the road with a micro-mobility device.
  • Frazzled from juggling multiple micro-mobility apps and keeping track of payment methods/subscriptions
  • Frustrated at NYC’s public transportation system because of unexpected and frequent delays
